One-Sentence Explanation: Known for gymnastic, 'comp-style' setting and very tall, impressive walls that can feel generous in grading.
Generally fair grading with massive, endurance-heavy lead walls that mimic outdoor pump.
Famous for 'vacation grades' that prioritize fun, flowy movement over raw difficulty.
Notorious for sandbagged, strength-dependent boulder problems and steep competition walls.
The standard for modern commercial grading; consistent, approachable, but rarely stiff.
Circuit grading system tends to encompass wide ranges, often leaning soft to remain accessible.
First gym in America; retains an 'old school' grit with stiff, technical, and often crimpy setting.
Widely considered one of the softest gyms in the West; beginner-friendly but grade-inflated.
Creative setting with specific crack features; grading is generally fair but can feel soft on big holds.
Uses unique 'Spot Scale' (1–5 spots); famous for top-outs and natural-feeling features that blur indoor/outdoor styles.
Focuses on broad accessibility with circuit grades that often feel easier than outdoor equivalents.
Uses grade ranges (e.g., V3–V5) which keeps things honest, though 'comp style' setting dominates.
Tall 60ft walls require serious endurance; older sets can feel particularly sandbagged and reachy.
Good mix of styles; grades are generally consistent for the region but softer than the Northeast.
Very commercialized atmosphere often results in 'feel good' grading for newer climbers.
Consistent 'triangular' distribution of grades; known for the 'Bike Rack' slab and fair ratings.
Uses a sometimes confusing 'ranged' tag system; generally considers member satisfaction over stiff grades.
Tourist-heavy location leads to approachable grading; a gym V6 might feel like an outdoor V3.
A strong local community keeps grading grounded, though still softer than the nearby steep outdoor crags.
Recently acquired by Movement; historically 'old school soft' but shifting toward standardized commercial grading.
Avondale is the 'climber's gym' of the chain, known for stiffer grades than its Uptown sibling.
Mixed bag; rope grades can be soft, but bouldering often feels stiff and technical/crimpy.
Community-driven vibe with grades that are fair but not discouraging; huge lead arches.
Modern, clean aesthetic with 'sterile' Walltopia walls; grading is color-coded and generally consistent.
Old school 'dungeon' vibe with tape grading; focused on raw power, crimps, and realistic difficulty.
Madison’s bouldering hub; circuits are broad, but the 'Black' circuit offers legitimate difficulty.
Well-rounded facility; grades are standard for the Midwest—approachable low end, stiff high end.
Heavily stylized 'boutique' gym; prioritizes aesthetics and accessibility, often resulting in softer grades.
The 'serious' gym of the area with tall, pumping lead walls that demand real endurance.
Like its sister gyms (SBP/ABP), the focus is on fun and flow, leading to accessible, softer grades.
High production value sets; grades can be inconsistent but generally hover around 'commercial medium'.
Cambridge location is known for being significantly stiffer and more power-focused than other CRG locations.
Widely cited as very soft; often criticized for 'low-balling' grades to encourage rapid progression.
Older walls with quirky, sometimes awkward setting that feels stiff and technical compared to modern gyms.
Original hipster gym vibe; historically soft grading to accommodate a high volume of casual climbers.
Built by climbers for climbers; no-frills training facility with arguably the stiffest grades in NYC.
Host to Nationals; setting leans heavily toward competition style (coordination/dynos) rather than outdoor simulation.
formerly Earth Treks; huge facility with 'feel good' grading designed to keep members happy.
Performance-focused setting that encourages progression; fair grades that aren't gift-wrapped.
Often hides grades on the back of tags to encourage trying routes; promotes experience over grade chasing.
